Marcel Dassault: The Visionary French Engineer and Industrialist

Marcel Dassault, born Marcel Ferdinand Bloch, was a renowned French engineer and industrialist who made a lasting impact on the aircraft manufacturing industry. He was also an accomplished politician, serving in both houses of the French Parliament for over three decades.

Early Life and Education

Born on January 23, 1892, in Paris, France, Dassault was the youngest of four children to Adolphe Bloch, a doctor, and his wife Nomie Allatini. His parents were Jewish, and he was educated at the prestigious Lyce Condorcet in Paris. After completing his studies in electrical engineering, Dassault graduated from the Breguet School and Suparo, where he was classmates with Mikhail Gurevich, a Russian student who would later become instrumental in the creation of the MiG aircraft series.

Career Highlights and Major Works

Dassault's career in aircraft manufacturing began during World War I, where he worked at the French Aeronautics Research Laboratory at Chalais-Meudon. During this time, he invented a type of aircraft propeller that was later used by the French army during the conflict. In 1916, he co-founded the Socit dtudes Aronautiques with Henry Potez and Louis Coroller, which produced the SEA series of fighters.

In 1928, Dassault founded the aircraft company Socit des Avions Marcel Bloch, which produced its first aircraft in 1930. In 1935, he entered into an agreement with Henry Potez to buy Socit Arienne Bordelaise SAB, which was later nationalized as the Socit Nationale de Constructions Aronautiques du Sud Ouest SNCASO in 1936. During this time, Dassault became the delegated administrator of the Minister for Air.

World War II and Resistance

During the occupation of France by Nazi Germany during World War II, Dassault refused to collaborate with the German occupiers at Bordeaux-Aronautique and was subsequently imprisoned by the Vichy government in 1940. However, his aircraft company continued to operate, producing aircraft parts for the German army. In 1944, Dassault was deported to the Buchenwald concentration camp, where he was imprisoned until the camp was liberated by the Allies in 1945.

Post-War Career and Legacy

After the war, Dassault continued to play a significant role in the French aircraft industry. In 1947, he founded the Dassault Aviation company, which produced the Ouragan, the first French military jet fighter. He also served as a member of the French Parliament, representing the Hauts-de-Seine department, from 1951 until his death in 1986.

Awards and Honors

Throughout his career, Dassault received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to the aircraft industry. In 1939, he was awarded the Grand Prix de l'Acadmie des Sciences for his work on aircraft design. He was also awarded the Grand-Croix de la Lgion d'Honneur, the highest French military honor, in 1974.

Personal Life and Milestones

Dassault married Madeleine Minckes in 1919, and they had two sons, Serge and Claude. He was known for his strong personality and his dedication to his work, often working long hours to achieve his goals.

Trivia and Fun Facts

Dassault's company, Dassault Aviation, is still one of the leading aircraft manufacturers in the world today.

He was a prolific inventor, holding over 100 patents in aircraft design and technology.

Dassault was a strong supporter of the Israeli state, and he played a key role in supplying Israel with military aircraft during the 1950s and 1960s.

Marcel Dassault's legacy is a testament to his innovative spirit, his dedication to his work, and his commitment to his country. He will always be remembered as one of the most influential figures in the history of aircraft manufacturing.
